Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2010 08:56AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:55AM by Margerie Melinda~  Your story and your photo are so powerful.  I was diagnosed in October 5 years ago.  I had Pinktober Rage for a few years.  It is truly an emotional mixed bag for me. Mostly I was pissed that these companies try to paint a pretty little pink picture of this horrible BEAST of a disease for COMPANY PROFIT.  That is really despicable.  The true philanthropists will not have caps on donations, no crappy percentage donated, and frankly will support breast cancer research/survivors/awareness/detection all year long.  I got all the pink ribbon stuff from well-meaning friends.  I gave them away, could not wear them.  It seemed like somehow wearing that stuff meant I was celebrating having breast cancer.  Early detection is not a cure, and it didn't exist at all for me or most of my bc friends.  How about the not-so-pretty awareness: you are never too young for breast cancer, you can still get it with no risk factors and no family history.  There is nothing fun or cute about breast cancer. Anyway, I still do not like the pink marketing.  It hurts less and less the further I get from diagnosis.  But this year was a truly turning point for me.  My son's peewee football coach asked the boys (I help coach the team, but no one knew I had bc) if they wanted to wear a hot pink sock on game days in October to support breast cancer awareness and the women who are fighting the disease.  These 8 &9 year old boys voted an unanimous yes.  They are so proud to wear their socks and support this cause.  They don't even make any money off of it.  I know my son is especially touched (not sure if he has told his team mates yet) that his friends are supporting a cause that has affected our family so tremendously.  Who knew a bunch of little kids could warm my cold pinkwashed heart?? My tag line "Are we there yet?" is sadly still there, because NO we are not there.  No Cause. No Cure. Still beautiful women fighting this disease every day. Beautiful women dying every day.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 02:08AM Margerie wrote: roxy,   It is good you discussed it with your doctor and I hope you get your beauty sleep with the Ambien.  I had trouble with insomnia too.  It started when I had chemo, then herceptin and has continued on Arimidex.  I tried a few sleeping aids (Lunesta, Ambien) but none of them worked.  I now take melatonin at bed time every night and sometimes take 50mg of benadryl if I happen to not have slept well the night before.  It works pretty well for me. So don't be afraid to try a different medication if the first one doesn't work, or you can try an herbal supplement like melatonin.  Hope the Sand Man has his sights on you!

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 04:17PM - edited Aug 13, 2008 04:21PM by Margerie I had kind of the same thing happen.  I was diagnosed Stage IIB and then a few months later they changed the criteria- my 5+ nodes meant now I was Stage IIIA.  Of course I freaked.  My onc told me my cancer didn't get worse, it just got reclassified. Statistics are ink on paper- not human beings.  But I would have to disagree that a Stage III breast cancer diagnosis is not a big deal.  Anyone that thinks so should try it Are you a couple of years into your AI treatment?  I have a couple more years to go.  I went to a naturopath doc and he has helped my quality of life quite a bit with supplements.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 10:25PM Margerie wrote: LOL Celtic, that is really Celtic Spirit!! :) Carol, I don't think canceritis is that uncommon after a cancer diagnosis.  I have personally have had ankle cancer, skin cancer, mouth cancer, rib cancer, hip cancer and brain cancer each for a few days duration.  Of course, I really didn't have anything going on in the cancer department, it was a spider bite, a twisted ankle, a mouth abrasion, a bruised rib.  I think in my case my chemo brain is so bad, I won't remember bumping something.  But the fear is once burned, twice shy.  I can't wait to get to the point where I just get a headache for crying out loud!!  I hope your rib area gives you peace very, very soon!

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 09:48PM Margerie wrote: Naomi, I had the EXACT same thing happen to me......they told me my dense breasts would get lumpier, but the good news was they "probably wouldn't get saggy" and the mammogram was "normal."  So when I did find another lump two years later, I almost blew it off, but something told me to get it checked out and the rest is history.  I would get too angry thinking about it- so I don't. But what they should have said was "We don't see any abnormality, but since your breasts are so dense, it would be hard to see any problem so we should follow up in 6 months."  Come to think of it- my breasts will never be saggy now because they are gone I also have two younger sisters (I was 38) and they are only able to get mammograms too.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 06:50PM - edited Apr 4, 2008 06:52PM by Margerie Hi Badboob- I am glad you like the donkeys.  It is baby season now and there is nothing cuter than a baby donkey running kind-of-crazy sideways on too long legs crying out a baby "EEEhawww!" Anyway, I know this sounds crazy, but I have heard of patients taking high doses of estrogen after long-term AI use and progression. The idea is those er+ cells are so deprived and so greedy for estrogen, that if you flood them with estrogen, the cancer cells can't handle it and they die.  I am looking for some articles.  Here is what I have found so far: http://breast-cancer-research.com/content/4/4/133 http://www.springerlink.com/content/x55x31t348723650/ I couldn't really find more info on Dr. Google, but maybe your onc has some information on it. Good luck on your treatment!
